Challenges.Name: I Have... Challenge
Challenges.Instruction:
Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. A link to the online Challenge Journal will be automatically sent to you every day in your email.

What we have learned from people at the very end of their lives is that they wished they had appreciated the simple things they had in their lives. The best things in life are truly free, though we often don't realize that until it's too late!

This challenge is about taking the time to notice ALL that you have and really appreciating it. And if you find yourself thinking about what you don't have, try to bring your mind back to all you do have. When you do, you'll start training your brain to focus on the good, and you'll find yourself feeling a lot better.
Challenges.WelcomeMessage: Sometimes we focus on what we don't have, and it makes us feel bad. See what happens when we focus on what we do have instead!

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 1 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

You've heard it before: the best things in life are free but it is so easy to forget that.  You can boost your happiness levels when you take a few minutes every day to notice and jot down all the things you have.
Instructions.EmailInstructions:
Welcome to Day 1 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

You've heard it before: the best things in life are free but it is so easy to forget that.  You can boost your happiness levels when you take a few minutes every day to notice and jot down all the things you have.

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 2 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

Researchers have found that taking just two minutes a day to write about positive things in our lives trains our brains to regularly scan our environment for positivity, which then makes us happier!
Instructions.EmailInstructions:
Welcome to Day 2 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

Researchers have found that taking just two minutes a day to write about positive things in our lives trains our brains to regularly scan our environment for positivity, which then makes us happier!

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 3 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

We know that what we focus on grows. If we focus on all that we don't have, our feelings of discontent and discouragement will grow. If we focus on all that we have, our feelings of abundance and happiness will grow.

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 4 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

Every time you focus on something that you don't have and you start to feel bad, interrupt that thought and think of something you do have. Choose to feel good.
Instructions.EmailInstructions:
Welcome to Day 4 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

Every time you focus on something that you don't have and you start to feel bad, interrupt that thought and think of something you do have. Choose to feel good.

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 5 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

No doubt we can all find things that aren't going well in our lives, but if we focus on these things, we will get anxious, panicky, jealous of others who "seem to have more," and we will feel like we are in a state of lack.  But when we focus on everything that is going well in our lives, we feel optimistic, relaxed, encouraged, full of abundance.

If I had to choose, I'd focus on the positive!  How about you?

Challenges.Name: Train Your Brain for Positivity Challenge
Challenges.Instruction:
Your challenge is to write for just two minutes a day about what went well in your day in your onsite Challenge Journal for 21 days in a row.  The research shows that it helps to build a positive brain!

Even if you're having a lousy day, search for just one thing that went well or that you appreciated. It may be experiences as simple as enjoying a cup of coffee, feeling the sun on your face or noticing that you can see or hear.

When you write about what went well do your best to feel the good feelings that went along with it. When we scan our environment every day for what is good and what is going well it helps form a mental habit of focusing on the good versus the bad. Even the worst day has something positive in it. Just take two minutes to write about it!
Challenges.WelcomeMessage: This challenge is designed to help you rewire your brain for positivity.  Start building a habit of scanning your environment for what's going well versus what's not.  Just watch and see what happens next!  Give it a try for just two minutes a day!
Challenges.ScienceBehind:
Research shows a positive mindset results in 23% greater energy in the midst of stress, 31% higher productivity, and a 40% higher likelihood to be promoted. "The greatest competitive advantage in the modern economy is a positive and engaged brain." says Sean Achor, author of Before Happiness and The Happiness Advantage.

In an article in Forbes magazine Shawn Achor said we should, "Create happiness hygiene." We eat, sleep and brush our teeth everyday, yet we neglect something crucial: priming our brain to positive. He recommends that we "create a two minute daily habit of thinking of 3 new things you are grateful for each day, journaling about a positive experience for two minutes, meditating by watching your breath go in and out, or writing a positive 2 minute email."

Forbes, Dan Schawbel, 9/10/2013

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 1 of your Train Your Brain for Positivity Challenge!  

Your challenge is to write for just two minutes a day about what went well in your day in your onsite Challenge Journal for 21 days in a row. 

According to research, writing about one positive experience you've had, once a day over a span of 21 days, will retrain your brain to seek happiness in the present and in how you experience your world. Try it - give it as a gift to yourself!

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 2 of your Train Your Brain for Positivity Challenge!  
 
Your challenge is to write for just two minutes a day about what went well in your day in your onsite Challenge Journal for 21 days in a row. 

Something good has happened in the last 24 hours. Even the crummiest day has one bright spot in it. You just have to think about it: what made you smile, laugh, or feel good? It's there, just step back and try to find it.

Your challenge is to write for just two minutes a day about what went well in your day in your onsite Challenge Journal for 21 days in a row. 

You don't have time? It's more like you don't have time not to!  Two of the most important minutes of your day are when you jot down a positive thing that happened in the last 24 hours.  Doing so will train your brain to see the positive things in life instead of the negative things. Everything has a positive side; train yourself to see it and see how much happier you can get!

Challenges.Name: Gratitude Versus Negative Attitude Challenge
Challenges.Instruction:
In this challenge, as much as possible throughout the day for 21 days, whenever you think of worrisome or negative thoughts, try to catch yourself doing it. When you do, try to think of something you are thankful for instead!

The second part of your challenge is to write about this experience for at least two minutes a day in your online Challenge Journal.  This challenge will help you become more aware of how often you worry, and help you disrupt the worry habit, and build a habit of gratitude instead.
Challenges.WelcomeMessage: This is an intense challenge that asks you to be vigilant about monitoring your negative thoughts, and then switching to positive ones instead. The outcome is powerful - it will help you build awareness of how much your mind focuses on worrisome and negative things so you can catch yourself and make a more positive choice.  It will also help you build a stronger attitude of gratitude!

Challenge.Name: I Have... Challenge
Challenge.Instruction:
Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. A link to the online Challenge Journal will be automatically sent to you every day in your email.

What we have learned from people at the very end of their lives is that they wished they had appreciated the simple things they had in their lives. The best things in life are truly free, though we often don't realize that until it's too late!

This challenge is about taking the time to notice ALL that you have and really appreciating it. And if you find yourself thinking about what you don't have, try to bring your mind back to all you do have. When you do, you'll start training your brain to focus on the good, and you'll find yourself feeling a lot better.
Challenge.WelcomeMessage: Sometimes we focus on what we don't have, and it makes us feel bad. See what happens when we focus on what we do have instead!

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 1 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

You've heard it before: the best things in life are free but it is so easy to forget that.  You can boost your happiness levels when you take a few minutes every day to notice and jot down all the things you have.
Instructions.EmailInstructions:
Welcome to Day 1 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

You've heard it before: the best things in life are free but it is so easy to forget that.  You can boost your happiness levels when you take a few minutes every day to notice and jot down all the things you have.

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 2 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

Researchers have found that taking just two minutes a day to write about positive things in our lives trains our brains to regularly scan our environment for positivity, which then makes us happier!
Instructions.EmailInstructions:
Welcome to Day 2 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

Researchers have found that taking just two minutes a day to write about positive things in our lives trains our brains to regularly scan our environment for positivity, which then makes us happier!

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 3 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

We know that what we focus on grows. If we focus on all that we don't have, our feelings of discontent and discouragement will grow. If we focus on all that we have, our feelings of abundance and happiness will grow.
Instructions.EmailInstructions:
Welcome to Day 3 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

We know that what we focus on grows. If we focus on all that we don't have, our feelings of discontent and discouragement will grow. If we focus on all that we have, our feelings of abundance and happiness will grow.

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 4 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

Every time you focus on something that you don't have and you start to feel bad, interrupt that thought and think of something you do have. Choose to feel good.
Instructions.EmailInstructions:
Welcome to Day 4 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

Every time you focus on something that you don't have and you start to feel bad, interrupt that thought and think of something you do have. Choose to feel good.

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 5 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

No doubt we can all find things that aren't going well in our lives, but if we focus on these things, we will get anxious, panicky, jealous of others who "seem to have more," and we will feel like we are in a state of lack.  But when we focus on everything that is going well in our lives, we feel optimistic, relaxed, encouraged, full of abundance.

If I had to choose, I'd focus on the positive!  How about you?

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 6 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

You are doing some real mental muscle building to focus on what is good in your life.  This challenge is going to help you feel more optimistic, hopeful, relaxed and happy. The more you do this, the more it will become a way of being and a way of life!  It'll get easier to do too!

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 7 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

Go ahead and focus on all the good things you have, and not just the material things.  It's so easy to forget to appreciate how far you've come and the good things you have brought into your life.  This is the time to remember!

Challenges.Name: I Have... Challenge
Challenges.Instruction:
Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. A link to the online Challenge Journal will be automatically sent to you every day in your email.

What we have learned from people at the very end of their lives is that they wished they had appreciated the simple things they had in their lives. The best things in life are truly free, though we often don't realize that until it's too late!

This challenge is about taking the time to notice ALL that you have and really appreciating it. And if you find yourself thinking about what you don't have, try to bring your mind back to all you do have. When you do, you'll start training your brain to focus on the good, and you'll find yourself feeling a lot better.
Challenges.WelcomeMessage: Sometimes we focus on what we don't have, and it makes us feel bad. See what happens when we focus on what we do have instead!

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 1 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

You've heard it before: the best things in life are free but it is so easy to forget that.  You can boost your happiness levels when you take a few minutes every day to notice and jot down all the things you have.

Challenges.Name: Train Your Brain for Positivity Challenge
Challenges.Instruction:
Your challenge is to write for just two minutes a day about what went well in your day in your onsite Challenge Journal for 21 days in a row.  The research shows that it helps to build a positive brain!

Even if you're having a lousy day, search for just one thing that went well or that you appreciated. It may be experiences as simple as enjoying a cup of coffee, feeling the sun on your face or noticing that you can see or hear.

When you write about what went well do your best to feel the good feelings that went along with it. When we scan our environment every day for what is good and what is going well it helps form a mental habit of focusing on the good versus the bad. Even the worst day has something positive in it. Just take two minutes to write about it!
Challenges.WelcomeMessage: This challenge is designed to help you rewire your brain for positivity.  Start building a habit of scanning your environment for what's going well versus what's not.  Just watch and see what happens next!  Give it a try for just two minutes a day!
Challenges.ScienceBehind:
Research shows a positive mindset results in 23% greater energy in the midst of stress, 31% higher productivity, and a 40% higher likelihood to be promoted. "The greatest competitive advantage in the modern economy is a positive and engaged brain." says Sean Achor, author of Before Happiness and The Happiness Advantage.

In an article in Forbes magazine Shawn Achor said we should, "Create happiness hygiene." We eat, sleep and brush our teeth everyday, yet we neglect something crucial: priming our brain to positive. He recommends that we "create a two minute daily habit of thinking of 3 new things you are grateful for each day, journaling about a positive experience for two minutes, meditating by watching your breath go in and out, or writing a positive 2 minute email."

Forbes, Dan Schawbel, 9/10/2013

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 1 of your Train Your Brain for Positivity Challenge!  

Your challenge is to write for just two minutes a day about what went well in your day in your onsite Challenge Journal for 21 days in a row. 

According to research, writing about one positive experience you've had, once a day over a span of 21 days, will retrain your brain to seek happiness in the present and in how you experience your world. Try it - give it as a gift to yourself!

Your challenge is to write for just two minutes a day about what went well in your day in your onsite Challenge Journal for 21 days in a row. 

You've heard it before: the best things in life are free but it is so easy to forget that.  You can boost your happiness levels when you take a few minutes every day to notice and jot down all the things you have.

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 7 of your Train Your Brain for Positivity Challenge!  

Your challenge is to write for just two minutes a day about what went well in your day in your onsite Challenge Journal for 21 days in a row. 

Researchers have found that taking just two minutes a day to write about positive things in our lives trains our brains to regularly scan our environment for positivity, which then makes us happier!

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 8 of your Train Your Brain for Positivity Challenge!  

Your challenge is to write for just two minutes a day about what went well in your day in your onsite Challenge Journal for 21 days in a row. 
We know that what we focus on grows. If we focus on all that we don't have, our feelings of discontent and discouragement will grow. If we focus on all that we have, our feelings of abundance and happiness will grow.

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 9 of your Train Your Brain for Positivity Challenge!  
 
Your challenge is to write for just two minutes a day about what went well in your day in your onsite Challenge Journal for 21 days in a row. 

Every time you focus on something that you don't have and you start to feel bad, interrupt that thought and think of something you do have. Choose to feel good.
Instructions.EmailInstructions:

Every time you focus on something that you don't have and you start to feel bad, interrupt that thought and think of something you do have. Choose to feel good.

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 10 of your Train Your Brain for Positivity Challenge!  

Your challenge is to write for just two minutes a day about what went well in your day in your onsite Challenge Journal for 21 days in a row. 

No doubt we can all find things that aren't going well in our lives, but if we focus on these things, we will get anxious, panicky, jealous of others who "seem to have more," and we will feel like we are in a state of lack.  But when we focus on everything that is going well in our lives, we feel optimistic, relaxed, encouraged, full of abundance.

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 11 of your Train Your Brain for Positivity Challenge!   

Your challenge is to write for just two minutes a day about what went well in your day in your onsite Challenge Journal for 21 days in a row.

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 14 of your Train Your Brain for Positivity Challenge!  

Your challenge is to write for just two minutes a day about what went well in your day in your onsite Challenge Journal for 21 days in a row. 

Even if you're having a lousy day, search for just one thing that went well or that you appreciated.  It may be experiences as simple as enjoying a cup of coffee, feeling the sun on your face or noticing that you can see or hear.  When you write about what went well do your best to feel the good feelings that went along with it.  When we scan our environment every day for what is good and what is going well it helps form a mental habit of focusing on the good versus the bad.  Even the worst day has something positive in it.  Just take two minutes to write about it.  The research shows that it helps to build a positive brain!

Challenges.Name: Gratitude Versus Negative Attitude Challenge
Challenges.Instruction:
In this challenge, as much as possible throughout the day for 21 days, whenever you think of worrisome or negative thoughts, try to catch yourself doing it. When you do, try to think of something you are thankful for instead!

The second part of your challenge is to write about this experience for at least two minutes a day in your online Challenge Journal.  This challenge will help you become more aware of how often you worry, and help you disrupt the worry habit, and build a habit of gratitude instead.
Challenges.WelcomeMessage: This is an intense challenge that asks you to be vigilant about monitoring your negative thoughts, and then switching to positive ones instead. The outcome is powerful - it will help you build awareness of how much your mind focuses on worrisome and negative things so you can catch yourself and make a more positive choice.  It will also help you build a stronger attitude of gratitude!

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 1 of your Gratitude versus Negative Attitude Challenge!

As much as possible throughout the day for 21 days, whenever you think of worrisome or negative thoughts, try to catch yourself doing it. When you do, try to think of something you are thankful for instead!  

The second part of your challenge is to write about this experience for at least two minutes a day in your online Challenge Journal.  This challenge will help you become more aware of how often you worry, and help you disrupt the worry habit, and build a habit of gratitude instead.

The second part of your challenge is to write about this experience for at least two minutes a day in your online Challenge Journal.  This challenge will help you become more aware of how often you worry, and help you disrupt the worry habit, and build a habit of gratitude instead.

example.Name: I Have... Challenge
example.Instruction:
Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. A link to the online Challenge Journal will be automatically sent to you every day in your email.

What we have learned from people at the very end of their lives is that they wished they had appreciated the simple things they had in their lives. The best things in life are truly free, though we often don't realize that until it's too late!

This challenge is about taking the time to notice ALL that you have and really appreciating it. And if you find yourself thinking about what you don't have, try to bring your mind back to all you do have. When you do, you'll start training your brain to focus on the good, and you'll find yourself feeling a lot better.
example.WelcomeMessage: Sometimes we focus on what we don't have, and it makes us feel bad. See what happens when we focus on what we do have instead!

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 1 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

You've heard it before: the best things in life are free but it is so easy to forget that.  You can boost your happiness levels when you take a few minutes every day to notice and jot down all the things you have.
Instructions.EmailInstructions:
Welcome to Day 1 of your I Have Challenge!

You've heard it before: the best things in life are free but it is so easy to forget that.  You can boost your happiness levels when you take a few minutes every day to notice and jot down all the things you have.

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 2 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

Researchers have found that taking just two minutes a day to write about positive things in our lives trains our brains to regularly scan our environment for positivity, which then makes us happier!
Instructions.EmailInstructions:
Welcome to Day 2 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

Researchers have found that taking just two minutes a day to write about positive things in our lives trains our brains to regularly scan our environment for positivity, which then makes us happier!

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 3 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

We know that what we focus on grows. If we focus on all that we don't have, our feelings of discontent and discouragement will grow. If we focus on all that we have, our feelings of abundance and happiness will grow.
Instructions.EmailInstructions:
Welcome to Day 3 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

We know that what we focus on grows. If we focus on all that we don't have, our feelings of discontent and discouragement will grow. If we focus on all that we have, our feelings of abundance and happiness will grow.

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 4 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

Every time you focus on something that you don't have and you start to feel bad, interrupt that thought and think of something you do have. Choose to feel good.
Instructions.EmailInstructions:
Welcome to Day 4 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

Every time you focus on something that you don't have and you start to feel bad, interrupt that thought and think of something you do have. Choose to feel good.

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 5 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

No doubt we can all find things that aren't going well in our lives, but if we focus on these things, we will get anxious, panicky, jealous of others who "seem to have more," and we will feel like we are in a state of lack.  But when we focus on everything that is going well in our lives, we feel optimistic, relaxed, encouraged, full of abundance.

If I had to choose, I'd focus on the positive!  How about you?

example.Name: I Have... Challenge
example.Instruction:
Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. A link to the online Challenge Journal will be automatically sent to you every day in your email.

What we have learned from people at the very end of their lives is that they wished they had appreciated the simple things they had in their lives. The best things in life are truly free, though we often don't realize that until it's too late!

This challenge is about taking the time to notice ALL that you have and really appreciating it. And if you find yourself thinking about what you don't have, try to bring your mind back to all you do have. When you do, you'll start training your brain to focus on the good, and you'll find yourself feeling a lot better.
example.WelcomeMessage: Sometimes we focus on what we don't have, and it makes us feel bad. See what happens when we focus on what we do have instead!

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 1 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

You've heard it before: the best things in life are free but it is so easy to forget that.  You can boost your happiness levels when you take a few minutes every day to notice and jot down all the things you have.
Instructions.EmailInstructions:

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

You've heard it before: the best things in life are free but it is so easy to forget that.  You can boost your happiness levels when you take a few minutes every day to notice and jot down all the things you have.

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 2 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

Researchers have found that taking just two minutes a day to write about positive things in our lives trains our brains to regularly scan our environment for positivity, which then makes us happier!
Instructions.EmailInstructions:
Welcome to Day 2 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

Researchers have found that taking just two minutes a day to write about positive things in our lives trains our brains to regularly scan our environment for positivity, which then makes us happier!

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 3 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

We know that what we focus on grows. If we focus on all that we don't have, our feelings of discontent and discouragement will grow. If we focus on all that we have, our feelings of abundance and happiness will grow.
Instructions.EmailInstructions:
Welcome to Day 3 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

We know that what we focus on grows. If we focus on all that we don't have, our feelings of discontent and discouragement will grow. If we focus on all that we have, our feelings of abundance and happiness will grow.

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 4 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

Every time you focus on something that you don't have and you start to feel bad, interrupt that thought and think of something you do have. Choose to feel good.
Instructions.EmailInstructions:
Welcome to Day 4 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

Every time you focus on something that you don't have and you start to feel bad, interrupt that thought and think of something you do have. Choose to feel good.

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 5 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

No doubt we can all find things that aren't going well in our lives, but if we focus on these things, we will get anxious, panicky, jealous of others who "seem to have more," and we will feel like we are in a state of lack.  But when we focus on everything that is going well in our lives, we feel optimistic, relaxed, encouraged, full of abundance.

If I had to choose, I'd focus on the positive!  How about you?

Challenge.Name: I Have... Challenge
Challenge.Instruction:
Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. A link to the online Challenge Journal will be automatically sent to you every day in your email.

What we have learned from people at the very end of their lives is that they wished they had appreciated the simple things they had in their lives. The best things in life are truly free, though we often don't realize that until it's too late!

This challenge is about taking the time to notice ALL that you have and really appreciating it. And if you find yourself thinking about what you don't have, try to bring your mind back to all you do have. When you do, you'll start training your brain to focus on the good, and you'll find yourself feeling a lot better.
Challenge.WelcomeMessage: Sometimes we focus on what we don't have, and it makes us feel bad. See what happens when we focus on what we do have instead!

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 1 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

You've heard it before: the best things in life are free but it is so easy to forget that.  You can boost your happiness levels when you take a few minutes every day to notice and jot down all the things you have.

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 2 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

Researchers have found that taking just two minutes a day to write about positive things in our lives trains our brains to regularly scan our environment for positivity, which then makes us happier!

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 3 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

We know that what we focus on grows. If we focus on all that we don't have, our feelings of discontent and discouragement will grow. If we focus on all that we have, our feelings of abundance and happiness will grow.

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 4 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

Every time you focus on something that you don't have and you start to feel bad, interrupt that thought and think of something you do have. Choose to feel good.
Instructions.EmailInstructions:
Welcome to Day 4 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal.

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 5 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

No doubt we can all find things that aren't going well in our lives, but if we focus on these things, we will get anxious, panicky, jealous of others who "seem to have more," and we will feel like we are in a state of lack.  But when we focus on everything that is going well in our lives, we feel optimistic, relaxed, encouraged, full of abundance.

If I had to choose, I'd focus on the positive!  How about you?

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal.

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 3 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

We know that what we focus on grows. If we focus on all that we don't have, our feelings of discontent and discouragement will grow. If we focus on all that we have, our feelings of abundance and happiness will grow.

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 4 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

Every time you focus on something that you don't have and you start to feel bad, interrupt that thought and think of something you do have. Choose to feel good.
Instructions.EmailInstructions:
Welcome to Day 4 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

Every time you focus on something that you don't have and you start to feel bad, interrupt that thought and think of something you do have. Choose to feel good.

Instructions.MilestoneInstructions:
Welcome to Day 5 of your I Have Challenge!

Your challenge is to focus on what "I Have" each day for 21 days, and write about it for at least two minutes in your online Challenge Journal. 

No doubt we can all find things that aren't going well in our lives, but if we focus on these things, we will get anxious, panicky, jealous of others who "seem to have more," and we will feel like we are in a state of lack.  But when we focus on everything that is going well in our lives, we feel optimistic, relaxed, encouraged, full of abundance.

If I had to choose, I'd focus on the positive!  How about you?
